content:
I spontaneously solved using what your code comments call "option 2". I'll be sure to explore option 1 next time, if I'm up to it.

I didn't exactly understand your last paragraph.
Is it actually needed?
I'm confused. How can the coins be "initially identical" if no two of them can share the same numbers?

Alice and Bob strike again :)

Bob doesn't know that a coin has an even number + an odd number on it, does he? I think this is not clear enough.

Does Alice stops as soon as the even numbers are deductible? In the example, only 3 faces are revealed, but you wrote "informs Bob he has seen enough to guess all the pairs of numbers on the coins". Maybe I'm missing something
It's actually finished (maybe apart from tags and generic title), simply submitting ad WIP to freeze time for a while.

Thanks for your comments. I updated the statement and added a simple commented example.
Bob actually knows the even/odd rule for coins.
Alice stops when all the even/odd pairs are deducible. The commented example should help.
That said, their friends Yulia and Zack are now playing!
I mean nothing else than the numbers can distinguish one coin from another.

Sorry, for some reason I missed this comment! It's not *actually* needed: If the bipartite graph has a unique perfect matching, then the expected (greedy) approach will always work. This approach is pretty natural (I believe it's easy to come up with it even without formalizing the problem too much) BUT it's not trivial to be convinced that it actually always works (given a perfect matching, if all vertices have degree >=2 then all vertices are incident to 1 matched + >=1 non-matched edge, hence simply alternating between matched and non-matched edges we end up in an alternating cycle, which can be swapped to form another perfect matching, contradicting the uniqueness, hence there always is a leaf, etc).

The idea of the last paragraph was to help people having this idea to be convinced that it will actually pass. Maybe it's too convoluted though...

(Also, if the expected approach was a bipartite matching algorithm, then I would probably have set the difficulty to hard.)

I re-solved (and published) with the greedy leaf detection, but now I'm not so sure I'd have attempted that in a "blind" contest setting.

I shouldn't have approved this, I'm not the appropriate target audience it seems.
Oh well.

Well, I kinda wanted a problem that would to be solvable by people not knowing anything about bipartite matching and at the same time that could encourage those who know to think about it twice.

It's indeed not fitted to a contest (where you would always go for the first approach that passes). BTW I changed my mind several times, my first version was: Say the score of a coin is the product (for instance) of its sides, given what Bob has seen, what is the maximum possible score for the set of coins chosen by Alice?
Nice! A slight change, and it sounds hardcore even though it's more or less the same thing.

Oh I see.

I'd suggest rephrasing as "Yulia has annotated both sides of N identical coins with the numbers from 1 to 2N."

The "initially" in the same sentence as "prepared" in a language with so little temporal cues... In common use, "preparing" *is* a way to set up an "initial" state!

ok I got it! Thanks for the update!

(I had no issue with Bob and Alice btw; on the contrary, I found it fun that they play another guessing game. Anyway, Yulia and Zack are fine too :D )
